Indications and doses

Symptomatic relief of allergy such as hay fever, urticaria, food allergy, drug reactions, Relief of itch associated with chickenpox,

By intramuscular injection or by intravenous injection

  • For adults
    4 mg every 4–6 hours; maximum 24 mg per day.
  • For adults elderly
    4 mg every 4–6 hours; maximum 12 mg per day.
  • For adults
    10 mg, repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.
  • For children 12–23 months
    1 mg twice daily.
  • For children 2–5 years
    1 mg every 4–6 hours; maximum 6 mg per day.
  • For children 6–11 years
    2 mg every 4–6 hours; maximum 12 mg per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    4 mg every 4–6 hours; maximum 24 mg per day.
  • For children 1–5 months
    250 micrograms/kg (max. per dose 2.5 mg), repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.
  • For children 6 months–5 years
    2.5 mg, repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.
  • For children 6–11 years
    5 mg, repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    10 mg, repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.

Emergency treatment of anaphylactic reactions,

By intramuscular injection or by intravenous injection

  • For adults
    10 mg, repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.
  • For children 1–5 months
    250 micrograms/kg (max. per dose 2.5 mg), repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.
  • For children 6 months–5 years
    2.5 mg, repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.
  • For children 6–11 years
    5 mg, repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    10 mg, repeated if necessary; maximum 4 doses per day.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Most manufacturers of antihistamines advise avoiding their use during pregnancy; however, there is no evidence of teratogenicity.

Use in the latter part of the third trimester may cause adverse effects in neonates such as irritability, paradoxical excitability, and tremor.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Avoid in severe liver disease—increased risk of coma.

Contra indications

  • Many antihistamines should be avoided in Acute porphyrias but chlorphenamine is thought to be safe
  • neonates: neonate (due to significant antimuscarinic activity) in neonates

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Blurred vision, dry mouth, gastro-intestinal disturbances, headache, psychomotor impairment, urinary retention,

rare: Anaphylaxis, angioedema, angle-closure glaucoma in adults, arrhythmias, bronchospasm, confusion, convulsions, depression, dizziness, extrapyramidal effects, hypersensitivity reactions, hypotension, liver dysfunction, palpitation, photosensitivity reactions, sleep disturbances, tremor,

notKnown: Antimuscarinic effects, blood disorders, exfoliative dermatitis, rashes, tinnitus,

Specific side effects

notKnown: CNS stimulation, irritant effects, transient hypotension, CNS stimulation, irritant effects, transient hypotension,

In adults

Elderly patients are more susceptible to side-effects.

In children

Children are more susceptible to side-effects.

In adults

Drowsiness is a significant side-effect with most of the older antihistamines although paradoxical stimulation may occur rarely, especially with high doses or in children and the elderly. Drowsiness may diminish after a few days of treatment and is considerably less of a problem with the newer antihistamines.

In children

Drowsiness is a significant side-effect with most of the older antihistamines although paradoxical stimulation may occur rarely in children, especially with high doses. Drowsiness may diminish after a few days of treatment and is considerably less of a problem with the newer antihistamines.

Directions for administration

With intravenous use in children

For intravenous injection, give over 1 minute; if small dose required, dilute with Sodium Chloride 0.9%.

Advice for patients and carers

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Chlorphenamine maleate for allergy symptoms

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/chlorphenamine-maleate-allergy-symptoms-0

Important safety information

MHRA/CHM advice (March 2008 and February 2009) Over-the-counter cough and cold medicines for children

Children under 6 years should not be given over-the-counter cough and cold medicines containing chlorphenamine.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Epilepsy
  • : prostatic hypertrophy in adults
  • pyloroduodenal obstruction
  • susceptibility to angle-closure glaucoma
  • urinary retention

Unlicensed use

In children

Injection not licensed for use in neonates.

Tablets not licensed for use in children under 6 years.

Syrup not licensed for use in children under 1 year.

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

With oral use

Chlorphenamine tablets may be prescribed.

Chlorphenamine oral solution may be prescribed.

Exceptions to legal category

With intramuscular use or intravenous use

Prescription only medicine restriction does not apply to chlorphenamine injection where administration is for saving life in emergency.

Prepared medicinal forms of CHLORPHENAMINE MALEATE
